question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\A particle moves in a straight
line according to a law of motion \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ), \emph{t}
$\geq$ 0, where \emph{t} is measured in seconds and \emph{s} in meters.
The acceleration function \emph{a}(\emph{t} ) is given by

\[\displaystyle
a(t)=12t-30\] The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and $f$(0) = 0.\\\\Find
the position function \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ).
sols:
If \emph{s} = $f$(''t \emph{) is the function describing the position of
the particle, then its derivative $f$'(}t'') is its velocity and its
second derivative the acceleration. This means we know that

\[\displaystyle
f''(t) = a(t)\] and so

\[\displaystyle
f''(t) = 12t-30\] Since this is a polynomial in \emph{t} of degree one,
we know that the velocity must be a polynomial of degree 2:

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = at^2+bt+c\] whose derivative is 12\emph{t}-30

\[\frac{d}{dt}\left( at^2+bt+c \right) = 2at+b\] Hence we have

\[\displaystyle
2a = 12 \qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-30\] And so the velocity is

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+c\] for some constant \emph{c}. Since the velocity
after 2 seconds is 0, we actually are being told that $f$'(2)=0 and hence

\[\displaystyle
6 \cdot 4 - 30 \cdot 2 + c = 0 \qquad \Rightarrow c=36\] And so the
velocity is

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+36\] Now, the velocity being the derivative of the
position function, we can deduce that it has to be a polynomial of
degree 3 and write

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = At^3+Bt^2+Ct+D\] and computing its derivative gives us

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 3At^2+2Bt+C\] Hence

\[\displaystyle
3A = 6 \qquad \text{and} \qquad 2B=-30 \qquad \text{and} \qquad C=36\]
So the position function is

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t+D\] and we can find out the value of \emph{D}
since we are told that $f$(0) = 0 which gives

\[\displaystyle
D=0\] And so finally, we obtain that the position function is:

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t\]
hints: The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.
